questions.text: An intern reviewing an MRI scan observes a "boxcar ventricle” This radiological finding is indicative of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Hereditary neurodegenerative disorder characterized by chorea, psychiatric symptoms, and cognitive decline.

Inheritance Pattern

Autosomal dominant due to a mutation in the HTT gene on chromosome 4 involving a CAG trinucleotide repeat.

Clinical Features

Chorea: Involuntary, irregular movements.

Mood Changes: Irritability and aggressive behavior.

Cognitive Decline: Progressive memory loss (dementia).
Radiological Findings

Atrophy of Caudate Nucleus: Leads to dilation of the frontal horn of the lateral ventricle.

"Boxcar Ventricles" Appearance: Resulting from caudate atrophy.

Definition

A rapidly progressive neurodegenerative disorder caused by prions—misfolded proteins that induce other proteins to misfold, leading to brain damage.

Clinical Features

Cognitive Decline: Rapid deterioration of mental function.

Behavioral Changes: Altered behavior and personality.

Myoclonus: Sudden muscle jerks.

Radiological Findings

Diffusion-weighted MRI Findings: Increased signal intensity in the basal ganglia (particularly in the putamen and caudate nuclei) and cortical ribboning.

Ventricular Enlargement: Atrophy leading to enlarged ventricles

Variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (vCJD)

A subtype of CJD associated with consumption of beef products contaminated with BSE (bovine spongiform encephalopathy).
Radiological Findings

Cortical Atrophy: Particularly in the occipital and parietal lobes.

Increased Signal Intensity on MRI: Observed in affected areas, especially in the basal ganglia and cerebral cortex.

Pulvinar Sign (Image A): Increased signal intensity in the pulvinar nucleus of the thalamus.

Hockey Stick Sign (Image B): A characteristic appearance on MRI, indicating involvement of the posterior thalamus.

Definition

A type of frontotemporal dementia characterized by early changes in personality, behavior, and social conduct.

Affected Areas

Primarily affects the frontal and temporal lobes.

Clinical Features

Behavioral Abnormalities: Significant personality changes and social withdrawal.
Radiological Findings

Prominent Sulci in the Frontal Lobe: Indicates atrophy of the frontal lobe.

Symmetric Disproportionate Atrophy of the Frontal Lobe: A hallmark distinguishing it from other forms of dementia.

Definition

The most common form of dementia, marked by progressive memory loss, cognitive decline, and changes in behavior and personality.

Pathophysiology

Accumulation of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles in the brain.

Clinical Features

Memory Impairment: Often the earliest symptom reported is difficulty remembering recent events.
Radiological Findings

Bilateral Symmetric Disproportionate Atrophy of the Hippocampus: Affects memory function.

Prominent Temporal Horns of the Lateral Ventricles: An indirect sign of hippocampal atrophy, indicating significant neurodegeneration in the temporal lobes.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with progressive motor decline, cognitive regression, and spasticity. MRI shows confluent and symmetric hyperintense T2 signals in the periventricular and deep white matter, with sparing of subcortical U fibers & tigroid pattern is noted. What is the underlying enzymatic deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Metachromatic leukodystrophy
  • Caused by a deficiency of the enzyme Arylsulfatase A (Option B)
  • Characterized by confluent and symmetric hyperintense T2 signals in the periventricular and deep white matter, while subcortical U fibers are relatively spared.
  • The perivenular myelin shows relative sparing, creating a tigroid pattern.
Alexander disease
  • Three clinical forms exist: infantile, juvenile, and adult, with the infantile form being the most common, presenting with macrocephaly.
  • Characteristic T2 hyperintense signal in bifrontal white matter.
  • Early disease may show intense post-contrast enhancement.
  • Histopathologically characterized by Rosenthal fibers in the brain.
Adrenoleukodystrophy
  • An inherited X-linked peroxisomal disorder caused by a mutation in the ABCD1 gene.
  • Accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids in the white matter.
  • Confluent T2 hyperintense signal in periventricular and deep white matter, especially in peritrigonal regions.
  • Marked rim enhancement on post-contrast T1 images at the leading edge indicates perivascular inflammation linked to demyelination.

Glutaric aciduria type I

  • It is caused by an inherited deficiency of the enzyme glutaryl-CoA. (Option D)
  • Atrophy or hypoplasia of the frontotemporal regions.
  • Enlarged anterior temporal subarachnoid spaces.
  • Cyst-like dilation of the Sylvian fissures with a "batwing" appearance.
Globoid Leukodystrophy (Krabbe’s Disease)

  • A lysosomal disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme β-galactocerebrosidase. (Option C)
  • CT shows symmetrical hyperdensity in the basal ganglia, thalami, cerebellum, and corona radiata.
  • Enlargement of the optic chiasm and optic nerves
  • MRI reveals confluent, symmetric T2 hyperintense signals in the periventricular and deep white matter.
  • Alternating hyperintense and hypointense signals in the cerebellar white matter surrounding the dentate nuclei.
Canavan Disease

  • An autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of the aspartoacylase enzyme. (Option A)
  • Leads to increased levels of N-acetyl aspartate (NAA) in the brain, resulting in spongiform degeneration of white matter, globus pallidus, and thalami.
  • Presents with macrocephaly and hypotonia
  • On MRI there is Involvement of subcortical U fibers, thalamus, and globus pallidus, with relative sparing of the internal capsules and putamen.
  • The distinctive finding on MR spectroscopy is an increase in N-acetylaspartate (NAA).

Peak and Metabolite

Normal Function

Condition

Lipid (1.3 ppm)

Marker of tissue necrosis

Tuberculosis, Glioblastoma, Cerebral infarction

N-Acetylaspartate (NAA, 2.0 ppm)

Marker of neuronal health and density

Canavan Disease, Alzheimer’s, Gliomas

Choline (Cho, 3.2 ppm)

Reflects cell membrane turnover

Tumors, Demyelinating diseases, Hepatic encephalopathy

Creatine (Cr, ~3.0 ppm)

Energy metabolism marker

Variable (often stable marker)

Lactate (1.3 ppm)

Anaerobic metabolism marker

Hypoxia, Stroke, Mitochondrial Disorders

Myo-inositol (~3.5 ppm)

Osmoregulation and glial cell marker

Alzheimer’s, Meningiomas, Hepatic encephalopathy

Acetate & Succinate (~2.0 ppm)

Intermediate metabolites in metabolic processes

Bacterial abscesses, Metabolic disorders

Taurine (~3.4 ppm)

Osmoregulation, bile salt conjugation

Pediatric brain tumors (e.g., medulloblastoma)

questions.text: A 75-year-old female presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of progressive difficulty in walking, frequent urinary urgency, and occasional episodes of confusion. Imaging is performed, revealing ventriculomegaly and effacement of the sulci at the vertex as shown. Which of the following statements about the condition is false?

options.label: A
options.text: It is idiopathic but can be caused due to past injuries

options.label: B
options.text: The Evans ratio is less than 0.31

options.label: C
options.text: The callosal angle is less than 90 degrees

options.label: D
options.text: A disproportionately enlarged subarachnoid space is seen

questions.correct_answer: B. The Evans ratio is less than 0.31
questions.explanation:
Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH)

NPH is often idiopathic but can result from prior injuries affecting cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) dynamics, such as subarachnoid hemorrhage. (Option A)

Clinical presentation
  • Gait disturbance: progressive difficulties in walking
  • Urinary issues: urgency or incontinence
  • Cognitive impairment: decline in cognitive functions

Imaging Characteristics
  • Ventriculomegaly is typically seen
  • Evans ratio: the ratio of the maximum width of frontal horns to inner table width of more than 0.31 is often used for evaluation but has low diagnostic accuracy.
  • An acute callosal angle (less than 90°) on coronal MR images is another measurement used, also with limited accuracy. (Option C)
  • A disproportionately enlarged subarachnoid space hydrocephalus (Option D) is seen having ventriculomegaly combined with sulcal effacement at the vertex and scattered enlarged sulci.
  • CSF flow study shows hyper-dynamism with a streak of flow void through cerebral aqueduct.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the pediatric neurologist with a history of recurrent seizures since he was 1 year old. Upon examination, a port wine stain is noted on the right side of his face. What imaging findings would you expect to see in this patient, considering Sturge–Weber Syndrome?

options.label: B
options.text: Cystic lesions with enhancing mural nodules in the cerebellum

options.label: C
options.text: Tramline calcifications and atrophy of the affected hemisphere

questions.correct_answer: C. Tramline calcifications and atrophy of the affected hemisphere

questions.text: An infant undergoes a brain MRI that reveals a crescent-shaped mass filling the entire ventricular system, with the interhemispheric fissure not visible. The cerebrum exhibits a pancake-like appearance of the cerebral tissue, and there are no identifiable structures of the corpus callosum or falx cerebri. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis for this infant?
questions.explanation:
Holoprosencephaly

  • Holoprosencephaly is a forebrain malformation caused by incomplete separation of the cerebral hemispheres, associated with facial deformities.
  • It has varying severity, classified into
    • Alobar
    • Semilobar
    • Lobar
    • Interhemispheric types

Imaging Findings:

  • Alobar:
    • Crescent-shaped holo ventricle with no interhemispheric fissure
    • Cerebrum has a pancake-like mass of tissue on imaging
    • No interhemispheric fissure, corpus callosum, or falx cerebri
  • Semilobar:
    • Partial separation of the hemispheres, presenting with a single ventricle
    • Mild facial abnormalities
  • Lobar (Option D):
    • Near-normal separation of hemispheres with some continuous cortex between the frontal lobes
    • Typically shows normal brain volume
  • Interhemispheric (Syntelencephaly):
    • Anterior and posterior fissures are present, but the middle lacks an interhemispheric fissure with fused frontal and parietal lobes

 

Schizencephaly (Option B):

  • Schizencephaly is a defect in the cerebral mantle characterized by a cleft that connects the calvarium with the lateral ventricles, lined with grey matter and leptomeninges.
  • The cleft can be classified as:
    • Open lip (wide-open defect)
    • Closed lip (closed but lined with grey matter)

Imaging Findings:

  • CT: lateral ventricles may show clefts and abnormalities in the cortical mantle.
  • MRI:
    • Closed lip forms are best visualized showing abnormal cortical thickness due to polymicrogyria
    • Potential contralateral developmental abnormalities are visualized as well

Lissencephaly (Option C):

  • Lissencephaly, or "smooth brain," involves abnormal neuronal migration resulting in a thickened cortex with few or no gyri, often associated with agenesis of the corpus callosum.
  • It can be categorized into complete lissencephaly (no gyri) and incomplete lissencephaly (fewer, broader gyri).

Imaging Findings:

  • MRI:
    • Shows a smooth cortical surface
    • Shallow and wide Sylvian fissures
    • A thin outer cortical layer with a thicker band of grey matter underneath

questions.text: The brain imaging of a child reveals the following: What is the classical appearance of the lateral ventricles in this image called?

A 3-month-old infant is evaluated for developmental delays and abnormal head shape. An MRI reveals a dysplastic cerebellum with an everted inferior vermis. Which type of Chiari malformation is most likely indicated by these findings?
questions.explanation:
Chiari Type I lesion or cerebellar ectopia

(Option A)

Chiari Type II malformations

Chiari Type III

(Option C)

Description

Involves the descent of normal cerebellar hemispheres below the foramen magnum, often with pointed tonsils.

Defined by a dysplastic

cerebellum with an

everted inferior vermis.
  • This is a rare type.
  • Involves herniation of the hindbrain (cerebellum with or without brainstem).

Anatomical changes

  • The cisterna magna is often obliterated.
  • Medulla oblongata elongation occurs leading to kinking as the fourth ventricle tail rolls over the spinal cord as it descends into the cervical canal.
  • Occipitalisation of the atlas and basilar invagination is seen.
  • The cerebellum herniates mainly involving the inferior vermis.
  • Medulla oblongata is elongated and may become kinked.
  • Compression and progressive degeneration of the brainstem, cerebellum, and upper spinal cord.
  • Brain anomalies of Type II
  • Occipital or cervical encephalocele
  • Occipital bone defect

 

Associated presentations

  • Patients become symptomatic only in adulthood and it is often associated with syringomyelia.
  • Ectopia of ≤2 mm is usually considered normal, while ≥5 mm is considered abnormal.
  • MRI findings tend to overestimate the prevalence.
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Dysplasia of the cerebral hemisphere, cranial vaults, and meninges.
  • Meningomyelocele is present in 98% of cases.
  • A low occipital or high cervical meningoencephalocele.

MRI images in the coronal plane

Fetal sonography findings
  • Lemon sign: flattening or inward scalloping or bowing of the frontal bone.
  • Banana sign: due to abnormal anterior curvature of the cerebellum or obliteration of cisterna magna.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with progressive headaches, vision changes, and growth delay. Neurological examination reveals bitemporal hemianopia. MRI of the brain shows a large, lobulated, multiloculated cystic lesion with a small enhancing solid component and calcifications in the suprasellar region. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Craniopharyngioma (Option B)
  • Craniopharyngiomas are suprasellar tumors that develop from remnants of the craniopharyngeal duct or Rathke’s pouch.
  • It compress Optic chaism leads to bitemporal hemianopia.
  • Adamantinomatous subtype
  • It is more common
  • Seen in children
  • Typically appear as large, lobulated, multiloculated cystic lesions with a small enhancing solid component and calcifications.
  • Papillary subtype
  • Seen in Adults
  • Primarily solid lesion
  • Rarely exhibit calcifications

Pituitary Adenoma (Option A)

Pituitary Microadenomas

  • Less than 10 mm in size.
  • Microadenomas appear isointense to the pituitary on T1-weighted images and slightly hyperintense on T2-weighted images.
  • In dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI, they enhance slowly compared to the surrounding pituitary gland.

Pituitary Macroadenomas

  • Larger than 10 mm in size.
  • Most of the macroadenomas are nonfunctioning.
  • They may cause endocrine disturbances or compress the optic chiasm, leading to bitemporal hemianopia.
  • Typically appear as sellar-suprasellar masses with a “snowman” or “figure of eight” appearance due to a waist at the diaphragma sellae.
  • The sella is usually enlarged.
  • These tumors can invade the cavernous sinuses.

Melanoma (Option C)
  • T1 Imaging: Typically hyperintense due to hemorrhage or melanin.
  • T2 Imaging: Typically hypointense.
  • T1 C+ Imaging: Shows enhancement usually in a peripheral rim pattern or a diffusely heterogeneous pattern.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with headache, nausea, and balance difficulties. MRI reveals a hyperdense mass in the midline cerebellar vermis, with surrounding vasogenic edema and hydrocephalus. The mass shows restricted diffusion on MRI and homogeneous contrast enhancement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ependymoma (Option A)

  • Ependymomas are glial tumors originating from the ependymal cells lining the brain's ventricles
  • Infratentorial (posterior fossa) tumors cause increased intracranial pressure and hydrocephalus.Supratentorial tumors cause focal neurological deficits, headaches, and seizures.
  • Associated with neurofibromatosis 2
  • Posterior fossa ependymomas: Appear as intraventricular masses filling the 4th ventricle, often extending through the foramina of Luschka and Magendie, resembling a "plaster cast."
  • Supratentorial ependymomas: Half are intraparenchymal.
  • Ependymomas show heterogeneity with areas of necrosis, calcification, cystic changes, and hemorrhage.
  • On MRI, they are hypointense on T1, hyperintense on T2, with heterogeneous enhancement and possible restricted diffusion.
Medulloblastoma (Option B)

  • Medulloblastomas are the most common malignant brain tumors in children.
  • It is typically present as well-defined, hyperdense masses in the midline cerebellar vermis, often with surrounding vasogenic edema, hydrocephalus, and homogeneous contrast enhancement.
  • These tumors are T1 hypointense, T2 hyperintense, and heterogeneously enhancing, with surrounding edema, mass effect, and restricted diffusion.
  • Typically arise in the midline cerebellar vermis.
  • These tumors often bulge from the roof of the fourth ventricle, leading to obstructive hydrocephalus in children.
  • CSF seeding is common at presentation.
Cerebellar Pilocytic Astrocytoma (Option C)

  • Pilocytic astrocytoma (PA) is a low-grade (WHO grade 1) astrocytoma, and it is well-circumscribed
  • It is the most common primary brain tumor in children
  • strongly associated with neurofibromatosis type I (NF1)
  • Cystic lesions with an enhancing mural nodule.
  • Cystic component typically shows fluid signal, with enhancement of the cyst wall
  • The solid mural nodule is hypointense on T1, hyperintense on T2, and shows intense enhancement.
Primary CNS Lymphoma (Option D)

  • Primary CNS Lymphoma is a rare type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma associated with EBV.
  • Primarily found in the periventricular area (along the ependymal surface of the ventricle) and within deep gray matter nuclei.
  • CT Scan: Displays solitary or multiple hyperdense, enhancing lesions
  • MRI: Lesions are typically hypointense on T1 and iso/hypointense to gray matter on T2-weighted images; most lesions exhibit intense homogeneous enhancement.
  • MR Spectroscopy: Characterized by low N-acetylaspartate (NAA), elevated choline peaks.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive SNHL and non-pulsatile tinnitus in the right ear. MRI reveals a solid, enhancing mass in the internal auditory canal extending into the cerebellopontine angle, creating an "ice cream cone" appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Vestibular Schwannoma (Option C)
  • Schwannomas are benign tumors that originate from Schwann cells forming the nerve sheath.
  • Commonly arise from superior & inferior vestibular divisions of the 8th cranial nerve
  • Usually solitary, B/L acoustic tumors are seen in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2).
  • presents with sensorineural hearing loss & nonpulsatile tinnitus.
  • On contrast-enhanced scans, it appears as solid, nodular enhancing masses in the internal auditory canal extending into the cerebellopontine angle cistern.
  • Extracanalicular extension can produce an "ice cream cone" appearance.
Meningioma (Option D)

  • Meningiomas arise from arachnoidal cap cells in the brain and spinal cord coverings.
  • They are the most common benign intracranial tumors.
  • Most common in females
  • Mostly sporadic but can be linked to NF-2 or prior cranial irradiation.
  • Meningiomas are dural based extra-axial masses that appear isointense to gray matter on both T1 and T2-weighted images.
  • They demonstrate intense homogeneous enhancement on post-contrast imaging, accompanied by a dural tail sign.
  • Characteristic imaging features:
  • CSF cleft sign (thin layer of CSF around the mass)
  • Cortical buckling
  • Widening of the subarachnoid space with visible pial arteries/veins,
  • Hyperostosis or erosion of the calvarium.
  • Mother in law sign (early enhancement during the arterial phase and remain opacified long after the venous phase has passed)
  • Calcification
Glioblastoma Multiforme (Option A)

  • Glioblastomas are aggressive, poorly differentiated WHO grade 4 astrocytic tumors
  • It appears as heterogeneous tumors with thick, irregular enhancing margins and central necrosis. They may also contain intratumoral vessels and hemorrhage.
  • T2 signal abnormalities surrounding the tumor represent a mix of vasogenic edema and infiltrating neoplastic cells.
  • They can invade the corpus callosum, crossing the midline in a butterfly configuration.
Oligodendroglioma (Option B)

  • Oligodendroglioma (Option B)Oligodendrogliomas are diffuse infiltrating glial tumors originating from oligodendrocytes and are characterized by IDH mutations and 1p/19q codeletion.
  • These tumors can be either WHO grade 2 (well-differentiated oligodendrogliomas) or WHO grade 3 (anaplastic oligodendrogliomas).
  • Typically occurs in the frontal lobe.
  • They are slow-growing, non-encapsulated, and tend to infiltrate the overlying cortex.
  • CT: Oligodendrogliomas are isodense to hypodense with calcification
  • MRI: Tumors are hypointense on T1 and hyperintense on T2. They generally do not enhance with contrast

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman with a family history of an autosomal dominant genetic disorder presents with recurrent seizures and developmental delay. On physical examination, she has red papules on her face consistent with adenoma sebaceum. Which of the following is not a radiologic finding typically associated with this condition?

A 25-year-old patient with a family history of an autosomal dominant condition was diagnosed with a mutation in chromosome 22 and advised to have an MRI every 2 years to monitor for tumors. An MRI scan was performed and shown below. Identify the radiological finding shown below that is most consistent with this chromosomal abnormality?

A 2-week-old neonate is evaluated for failure to thrive and persistent tachycardia. A cranial MRI shows a large vascular malformation with multiple feeding arteries and a dilated vein of Galen. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Mural type Vein of Galen Malformation

options.label: B
options.text: Choroidal type Vein of Galen Malformation

questions.correct_answer: B. Choroidal type Vein of Galen Malformation
questions.explanation:
Vein of Galen Malformation

It is an arteriovenous malformation (AVM) developing prenatally due to abnormal connections (arteriovenous fistulas) involving the median prosencephalic vein which is a precursor to the vein of Galen.

  • Types of VGM:
    • Choroidal type (Option B)
      • Fed by multiple choroidal arteries forming a nidus anterior to the venous varix.
      • Presents in the neonatal period with high-output heart failure.
    • Mural type (Option A)
      • Characterized by fewer, more defined fistulous connections within the wall of the venous varix.
      • Presents later in infancy with symptoms such as hydrocephalus.
  • The dilated median prosencephalic vein (MPV) appears as a fluid-filled, echo-free structure in the posterior midline, showing significant blood flow on Doppler examination.
  • On T2-weighted images, dilated feeding and draining vessels appear as flow-voids.
  • The primary treatment involves endovascular procedures.
Arteriovenous (AV) malformation (Option C)

  • AVM is an abnormal tangle of vessels connecting an artery to a vein without a normal capillary bed.
  • Clinically present as Acute hemorrhage.
  • AVMs consist of several components:
  • Feeding arteries – supply blood to the malformation
  • Nidus (meaning "nest") – the central part where abnormal connections occur
  • Shunting arterioles – the main issue, causing direct blood flow from arteries to veins
  • Interconnected venous loops
  • Draining veins – carry blood away from the malformation
  • Early appearance of draining veins during the arterial phase of cerebral angiography indicates the presence of an arteriovenous shunt.
  • CECT shows a "bag of worms" appearance.
  • Fast blood flow creates flow voids visible on T2-weighted images.
Developmental venous anomaly (Option D)

  • Congenital malformation of veins that drain the normal brain.
  • It is the most common cerebrovascular malformation.
  • "Caput medusae" sign (collection of dilated medullary veins converging into an enlarged transcortical or subependymal collector vein) is pathognomonic and is observed in the venous phase of angiography.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a 2-week history of worsening headache, fever, and progressive neurological deficits, including weakness in his right arm. He has no significant past medical history. On examination, he exhibits right-sided hemiparesis and mild confusion. Blood tests show mild leukocytosis. A CT image is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old patient presents with epilepsy and progressive memory loss over the past year. Neuroimaging reveals hippocampal volume loss and abnormal signal intensity on high-resolution coronal MRI. The internal laminated architecture of the hippocampus is disrupted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Mesial temporal sclerosis (MTS)
  • MTS primarily affects the hippocampus, a key region in the medial temporal lobe responsible for memory.
  • Best visualized on high-resolution coronal MRI which demonstrates Hippocampa
    • Volume loss.
    • Abnormal signal.
    • Loss of normal internal laminated architecture.
  • MTS may cause atrophy in the ipsilateral mammillary body or fornix due to their connection within the medial limbic (Papez) circuit.
Devic’s disease
  • Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) typically presents with optic neuritis and transverse myelitis, along with additional demyelination.
  • It has overlapping clinical and radiographic features of multiple sclerosis.
  • Antibodies involved in NMO target astrocyte aquaporin-4 channels, myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein, and neurofascin at the node of Ranvier.
  • Spinal cord involvement typically presents as a high T2 signal that spans at least 3 vertebral segments, referred to as a longitudinally extensive spinal cord lesion.
Multiple sclerosis

  • MS is considered an autoimmune disease with elevated antibodies to glial antigens (e.g., CSF oligoclonal bands).
  • Optic neuritis is common in MS.
  • Dawson's fingers (lesions radiating perpendicularly from the corpus callosum), hyperintense lesions on T2-weighted and FLAIR images.
  • Hypointense "black holes" on T1-weighted images.
  • T1 C+ (Gadolinium): Active lesions enhance, often showing incomplete enhancement ("open ring sign").

McDonald's criteria used for MS diagnosis

Dissemination in Space:

Requires T2 bright lesions in two or more of the following locations:

  • Periventricular (≥3 lesions)
  • Cortical or juxtacortical (≥1 lesion)
  • Optic nerve (≥1 lesion)
  • Infratentorial (≥1 lesion)
  • Spinal cord (≥1 lesion)
 

Dissemination in Time:

Established by:

  • A new lesion on a follow-up scan
  • A T2 bright or gadolinium-enhancing lesion
  • An asymptomatic enhancing lesion with a non-enhancing T2 bright lesion on the same scan.

Primary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis (PPMS):

Requires:

  • ≥1 year of disease progression
  • Fulfillment of space dissemination criteria

Early Diagnosis:

  • Possible with clinically isolated syndrome and evidence of space dissemination on MRI or CSF-specific oligoclonal bands, without the need for time dissemination.
  • Both symptomatic and asymptomatic MRI lesions (excluding the optic nerve) can be used for dissemination assessment.

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with symptoms of confusion, ataxia, and memory impairment. He has a history of Alcoholic Liver Disease. An MRI is ordered to assess any potential brain damage due to chronic alcohol abuse. The MRI reveals signaling abnormalities. Which of the following locations are likely to show abnormal signals? Locations: Mammillary bodies Periventricular grey matter Thalamus Corpus callosum Hippocampus
questions.explanation:
Pathophysiology

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency caused by chronic alcoholism, leading to impaired glucose metabolism and brain dysfunction, particularly in memory and coordination areas.

Clinical Features

Mnemonic: GOA

Global Confusion: Mental disorientation, concentration issues, memory loss.

Ophthalmoplegia: Paralysis or weakness of eye muscles, nystagmus, or double vision.

Ataxia: Gait and stance disturbances due to cerebellar dysfunction.

Progression

Can lead to Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome, characterized by irreversible memory deficits and confabulation.

Diagnostic Test

Red Blood Cell Transketolase Test: Assesses thiamine deficiency.
MRI Findings

Signaling abnormalities seen in

  • Mammillary Bodies: Atrophy or hyperintensity.
  • Periventricular Gray Matter
  • Thalamus.
  • Midbrain Colliculi.
  • Fornix involvement.

Treatment
  • Immediate Thiamine Supplementation: Administer thiamine (typically 100 mg IV or IM).
  • Glucose Infusion: After thiamine is given, a glucose-containing solution can be infused, 

Pathophysiology

Rare condition affecting chronic alcoholics, causing demyelination and necrosis of the corpus callosum.

The mechanism is not fully understood, but it's linked to malnutrition and chronic alcohol toxicity.

Clinical Features

Cognitive Disturbances: Progressive dementia, confusion, memory loss.

Motor Symptoms: Seizures, gait abnormalities, spasticity.

Altered Sensorium: Lethargy, stupor, or coma.

Progression

Can lead to severe cognitive impairment, spasticity, coma, or death. The condition may worsen rapidly or fluctuate over time.
MRI Findings

Hyperintense lesions on T2-weighted and FLAIR sequences in the corpus callosum, especially the body and splenium.

 

Signs:

1. "Butterfly-shaped" lesions in the corpus callosum

2. Sandwich sign

Treatment

Thiamine and vitamin B-complex supplementation is usually administered.

Pathophysiology
  • Occurs due to rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia, leading to osmotic shifts and destruction of the myelin sheath in the central pons and other areas (e.g., basal ganglia).
 
  • Chronic alcoholics are at higher risk due to electrolyte imbalances.
Signs
  • Piglet sign: Characteristic imaging pattern in the central pons.
  • Trident sign: Imaging hallmark resembling a trident, indicating myelinolysis.

Clinical Features
  • Altered Sensorium: Ranges from confusion and disorientation to stupor or coma.
  • Quadriparesis: Severe weakness in all four limbs.
  • Rapid Deterioration: Symptoms can progress quickly, leading to coma or death if untreated.

Treatment

Slow correction of sodium levels in chronic hyponatremia is essential to avoid ODS.

questions.text: Assertion: The absence of the swallow tail on MRI is indicative of Parkinson's disease. Reason: It represents the characteristic loss of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra, leading to specific changes in the brain's morphology.

options.label: A
options.text: Both the assertion and reason are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion.

options.label: B
options.text: Both the assertion and reason are true, but the reason does not correctly explain the assertion.

options.label: C
options.text: The assertion is true, but the reason is false.

options.label: D

questions.text: Match the following diseases and their associated radiological signs Radiological Sign Disease 1) Giant Panda sign a) Ceruloplasmin Defeciency 2) tram track calcification b) Fahr’s Disease 3) Eye of the tiger sign c) Sturge Weber syndrome 4) Bracket Calcification d) Hallervorden-Spatz disease
questions.explanation:
Condition

Cause

Radiological Features
Wilson’s Disease Genetic disorder leading to low levels of ceruloplasmin, impairing copper transport and resulting in copper accumulation.

MRI: "Face of the giant panda" sign in the midbrain; signal abnormalities in basal ganglia due to copper deposits.

KF ring: Golden-brown ring in the cornea due to copper accumulation.

Note:

Sarcoidosis:

Gallium scan: Distinctive "panda sign" showing tracer uptake in the lacrimal, parotid, and salivary glands.

This should not be confused with the panda sign of Wilson's disease seen on MRI.
Hallervorden-Spatz Disease (PKAN) Iron accumulation in the brain, especially the globus pallidus.

MRI: "Eye of the tiger" sign on T2-weighted imaging. Central hyperintense gliotic area surrounded by hypointense iron deposits, resembling a tiger's eye.
Fahr’s Disease (Basal Ganglia Calcification) Idiopathic or secondary to metabolic disorders (e.g., hypoparathyroidism).

CT scan: Symmetrical calcifications in the basal ganglia, thalamus, dentate nucleus, and other brain structures.

Bracket calcifications: Curvilinear hyperdensities forming a bracket-like appearance around the basal ganglia.
Sturge-Weber Syndrome Congenital neurocutaneous disorder with vascular malformations.

CT scan: "Tram-track" calcifications along the gyri of the cerebral cortex, especially in the occipital and parietal lobes.

MRI: Cortical atrophy and leptomeningeal enhancement.

Hypoparathyroidism

Leads to chronic hypocalcemia and can cause calcification in the basal ganglia due to calcium imbalance.

Familial Idiopathic Cerebral Calcification (Fahr's syndrome)

A genetic condition characterized by bilateral calcifications in the basal ganglia.

Bracket calcifications: Curvilinear hyperdensities forming a bracket-like appearance around the basal ganglia.

Perinatal Hypoxia

Lack of oxygen during or immediately after birth can result in calcification in the brain, including the basal ganglia.

Carbon Monoxide Intoxication

Exposure leads to bilateral calcifications in the globus pallidus, affecting neurological function.

Lead Poisoning

Chronic exposure can result in various neurological symptoms, including calcifications.

Cockayne Syndrome

A genetic disorder leading to calcification in the basal ganglia among other symptoms.

questions.text: An 80-year-old male presents to his physician with complaints of difficulty sleeping and frequently waking up during the night. He denies any accompanying symptoms, such as pain, anxiety, or other disturbances. Concerned about his sleep issues, the physician orders an MRI scan of the brain. The MRI findings reveal an appearance commonly referred to as "brain sand." Based on the findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Site

Location

Description

Physiological Function
Pineal Calcification

Posterior to the third ventricle

Known as "brain sand" (corpora arenacea); increases with age.


 		 Involved in melatonin production and regulation of circadian rhythms.
Choroid Plexus Calcification

Lateral ventricles

 Benign calcification that produces cerebrospinal fluid (CSF); often a normal finding with age. Responsible for CSF production.
Falx Cerebri Calcification

Midline of the brain

 Calcification along the sickle-shaped fold of dura mater; common aging change. No specific physiological role; considered a normal anatomical change.
Basal Ganglia Calcification

Globus pallidus and surrounding areas

Common in elderly individuals; not usually associated with neurological impairment.

 Associated with aging processes

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with persistent jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, petechiae, and microcephaly. On further evaluation, the infant is found to have sensorineural hearing loss and signs of developmental delay. The mother reports a history of a flu-like illness during pregnancy. A CT scan of the infant's brain reveals the following findings. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Infection

Type of Calcification

Affected Brain Region

Key Features

Congenital Toxoplasmosis (Option B)

Diffuse or nodular intracranial

Basal ganglia, cerebral cortex

Hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, developmental delays

Periventricular calcifications

Periventricular region

(Option C)

Congenital Rubella (Option A)

Microcephaly, cataracts, deafness, heart defects

Definition

A type of white matter brain injury affecting premature infants, characterized by the death of small areas of brain tissue around the ventricles due to ischemia.

Risk Factors
  • Premature birth (especially before 32 weeks of gestation)
  • Low birth weight
  • Neonatal infections

Location

Periventricular area (white matter near the lateral ventricles of the brain)

Causes
  • Ischemia (lack of blood flow)
  • Infection or inflammation during white matter development
  • Maternal infections or severe fetal distress

Pathophysiology

Premature infants (underdeveloped brain) → White matter (myelinated nerve fibers) is susceptible to damage → Ischemia (reduced blood flow) and hypoxia (low oxygen levels) → Injury and destruction of oligodendrocytes → Impaired myelin formation → Inadequate myelination → Deficits in motor function and other neurological impairments.

Clinical Features
  • Early signs may include abnormal muscle tone (hypotonia, spasticity) and abnormal movements.
  • Developmental delays.
  • Cerebral palsy (leading to spastic diplegia).
  • Possible cognitive impairments, including intellectual disabilities and visual disturbances.

Diagnosis

Neuroimaging:

  • Cranial Ultrasound: Detects brain abnormalities in premature infants.
  • MRI: Gold standard for identifying PVL, showing white matter damage.
  • CT Scans: May detect calcifications but are less sensitive than MRI.

Management
  • Supportive care: Focuses on symptom management and optimizing development.
  • Rehabilitation: Includes physical therapy, occupational therapy, and speech therapy.
  • Medications: May include antispasmodics for spasticity management.

Prognosis

Varies widely; some children experience mild developmental delays, while others may have severe disabilities such as cerebral palsy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of HIV presents to the emergency department with new-onset seizures and altered mental status. His CD4 count is 80 cells/mm³. A brain MRI is performed to evaluate for potential infections and is as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
A 32-year-old male presents with recurrent seizures. MRI imaging reveals as follows: Based on the MRI findings, which stage of neurocysticercosis is most consistent with this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Neurocysticercosis
  • Neurocysticercosis is the most critical parasitic disease of the central nervous system (CNS) globally.
  • It is caused by the encysted larvae of the tapeworm Taenia solium, transmitted through:
    • Ingesting eggs from undercooked pork
    • Fecal-oral transmission between humans
  • Larvae are spread to neural, muscular, and ocular tissues via the bloodstream.
  • The symptoms typically appear around 5 years after initial infection and are non-specific; 50%–70% of patients present with epilepsy.
  • Larvae can infect the brain parenchyma, subarachnoid space, and ventricles. The most common form is parenchymal, followed by intraventricular. Mixed types may also occur.

Imaging Stages of Parenchymal Neurocysticercosis

Vesicular stage
  • Viable larva with a scolex (worm head).
  • Cysts have thin walls, minimal enhancement, and no surrounding edema.
  • Cyst fluid resembles cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and allows unrestricted water diffusion.
  • The scolex may appear hyperintense on T1, FLAIR, and DWI images.
Colloidal vesicular stage (Option C)
  • Larva begins to break down, triggering an immune response.
  • Characterized by ring-enhancing lesions, perilesional edema, and mass effect.
  • Cyst content becomes more proteinaceous, appearing hyperintense on T1 and FLAIR images.

Granular nodular stage (Option A)
  • As the larva dies, the cyst collapses, leading to thick enhancing cyst walls and increased surrounding edema.

 
Calcified nodular stage (Option D)
  • Represents the inactive form of neurocysticercosis.
  • Edema resolves, revealing small calcified lesions (2–10 mm in diameter).
  • Contrast enhancement and edema are rare but can occur during seizure activity.
Intraventricular cysticercosis
  • The second most common form, with larvae more frequently located in the third and fourth ventricles.
  • Can obstruct CSF flow, potentially causing hydrocephalus, which may present acutely.
Subarachnoid cysticercosis
  • Involves areas such as basal cisterns, Sylvian fissures, and cerebellopontine angles.
Racemose cysticercosis is a rare form characterized by multiple clustered cysts separated by septae, resembling a ‘bunch of grapes,’ and can cause significant local meningeal enhancement.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male, an HIV-positive patient, presents with fever, headache, and confusion for the past week. Neurological examination reveals neck stiffness and altered mental status. CT shows basal meningeal enhancement and hydrocephalus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Tuberculous meningitis

  • Tuberculous meningitis is the most frequent CNS manifestation.
  • Early disease shows diffuse leptomeningeal enhancement; later stages typically involve the basal leptomeninges, especially in the interpeduncular cistern.

Imaging Findings:

  • CT Findings:
    • Obliteration of basal cisterns due to isoattenuating or hyperattenuating exudate.
    • Sensitive indicators: linear enhancement of middle cerebral artery cisterns, obliteration of CSF spaces, Y-shaped enhancement at the suprasellar/middle cerebral artery junction, and asymmetric enhancement.
    • Hydrocephalus is common at diagnosis.
  • MRI Advantages:
    • Greater sensitivity for detecting basal meningeal enhancement, hydrocephalus, and infarcts in perforator territories.

Intracranial Tuberculomas (Option A)

Most commonly found at the junction of white and grey matter.

CT Appearance:

  • Present as small, rounded lesions iso or hypo attenuating to normal brain tissue with variable surrounding vasogenic edema.
  • Homogeneous contrast enhancement in solid lesions; rim enhancement indicates central caseation or liquefaction.
  • The "target sign" (central high attenuation with rim enhancement) is not definitive for tuberculomas.

MRI Characteristics:

  • Small, non-caseated tuberculomas exhibit low signal intensity on T1 and high signal on T2 sequences.
  • Caseation leads to low signal intensity on T2.
  • On DWI, tuberculomas may show either elevated or restricted diffusion.
  • MR Spectroscopy shows a prominent lipid peak at 1.3ppm

 

Miliary Tuberculosis (Option D)

Characterized by multiple small (<5 mm) enhancing granulomas scattered throughout the brain, which may calcify over time.

TB Abscess

  • Single supratentorial abscess at the gray–white matter interface.
  • CT appearance: hyperdense rim with low-density center.
  • MRI appearance: abscess wall slightly T1-hyperintense and T2-hypointense; central contents are T1 hypointense and T2 hyperintense, with irregular dense wall enhancement and significant perilesional edema.
  • More common in elderly and immunocompromised individuals; larger than tuberculomas, often multiloculated, with thicker peripheral enhancement

Normal Function

Condition
